subsection.title: Quadratic Equations
subsection.p: So far you have learned how to solve linear equations. In linear equations, the variable cannot have any exponent other than 1, and for this reason such equations are often called first-degree. In this chapter we'll consider second-degree equations, or quadratic equations.

assemblage.title: Quadratic Equations
assemblage.p: A quadratic equation can be written in the standard form ax^2+bx+c=0 where a,~b, and c are constants, and a is not zero.

statement.p: Some examples of quadratic equations are 2x^2+5x-3=0,~~~~7t-t^2=0,~~~~\text{and}~~~~3w^2=16 The first equation is already written in standard form, with a=2,~b=5 and c=-3. In standard form, the other two equations are -t^2+7t+0 \amp =0 \amp \amp \text{so} ~ a=-1,~b=7,~ \text{and}~ c=0 3w^2+0w-16 \amp =0 \amp \amp \text{so} ~ a=3,~b=0,~ \text{and}~ c=-16

subsection.p: The numbers a,~b, and c are called parameters. They are the coefficients of, respectively, the quadratic term (the x^2-term), the linear term (the x-term), and the constant term.

warning.p: The x^2-term and the x-term in a quadratic expression are not like terms, so they cannot be combined.

statement.p: What is a quadratic equation? Give an example.

answer.p: An equation of the form ax^2+bx+c=0

sidebyside.p:
Quadratic equations appear in a variety of applications. A quadratic equation in two variables has the form y=ax^2+bx+c,~~a \not= 0 Its graph is not a straight line, but a curve called a parabola. The simplest, or basic, parabola is the graph of y=x^2, shown in the figure.
x -3 -2 -1 0 1 2 3
y 9 4 1 0 1 4 9

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: In the equation for the basic parabola, y=x^2, we have a=1,~b=0, and c=0. If the parameters have different values, the appearance or location of the graph will be altered. Example 2 illustrates a parabola that is shifted downward by 4 units.

subsection.title: Solving Quadratic Equations
subsection.p: Consider a simple quadratic equation, x^2=16 This equation tells us that x is a number whose square is 16. Thus, x must be a square root of 16. Now, 16 has two square roots, 4 and -4, so these are the solutions of the equation.

sidebyside.p: Remember that every positive number has two square roots, so the equation has two solutions, x=4 and x=-4. We can also see the two solutions on a graph. The figure at right shows the graph of y=x^2 and a horizontal line at y=16. There are two points on the graph with y-coordinate 16, and their y-coordinates are 4 and -4.

statement.p:
Solve each equation without using a calculator.
t^2=10,000
b^2=\dfrac{4}{9}
h^2=0.04
m^2=(-17)^2

solution.p:
For each equation, we find the square root of the right side. (That is, we find a number whose square gives the right side.) Remember that every positive number has two square roots.
Because ~~100^2=10,000,~~t=\pm 100
Because ~~(\dfrac{2}{3})^2=\dfrac{4}{9},~~b=\pm \dfrac{2}{3}
Because ~~0.2^2=0.04,~~h=\pm 0.2
Because ~~17^2=(-17)^2,~~m=\pm 17

statement.p: Why do the equations in Example 3 have two solutions?

answer.p: Because every positive number has two square roots.

subsection.title: Extraction of Roots

stack.p: The figure at right shows a graph of the quadratic equation y=2x^2-5.
You can see that there are two points on the graph for each y-value greater than -5. For example, the two points with y-coordinate 7 are shown.

subsection.p: To solve the quadratic equation 2x^2-5=7 we need only find the x-coordinates of these points. From the graph, the solutions appear to be about 2.5 and -2.5.
How can we solve this equation algebraically? We use the fact that taking square roots is the opposite of squaring.

subsection.p: This method for solving quadratic equations is called extraction of roots. The method applies to quadratic equation of the form ax^2+c=0, where the linear term bx is missing.

assemblage.title: Extraction of Roots
assemblage.p:
To solve a quadratic equation of the form ax^2+c=0
Isolate x^2 on one side of the equation.
Take the square root of each side.

statement.p: Explain how to solve the equation ax^2+c=0.

answer.p: Isolate x^2, then take square roots.

statement.p: Why does the equation ax^2+c=0 have two solutions?

answer.p: Every positive number has two square roots.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In the next Example we compare evaluating a quadratic expression and solving a quadratic equation.

statement.p:
A cat falls off a tree branch 20 feet above the ground. Its height t seconds later is given by h=20-16t^2.
What is the height of the cat 0.5 second later?
How long does the cat have to get in position to land on its feet before it reaches the ground?

stack.p: We would like to find the value of t when the height, h, is known. We substitute h=0 into the equation to obtain \alert{0}=20-16t^2 To solve this equation we use extraction of roots. We first isolate t^2 on one side of the equation. 16t^2 \amp = 20 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide by 16.}} t^2 \amp = \dfrac{20}{16} - 1.25

sidebyside.p: Next, we take the square root of both sides of the equation to find t= \pm \sqrt{1.25} \approx \pm 1.118 Only the positive solution makes sense here, so the cat has approximately 1.12 seconds to be in position for landing. A graph of the cat's height after t seconds is shown at right. The points corresponding to parts (a) and (b) are labeled.

subsection.title: Solving Formulas
subsection.p: Extraction of roots can be used to solve some formulas with a quadratic term.
